author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Review: A Satire of Social Media That Aims at Too Many Targets
description: Michael Breslin and Patrick Foley’s virtual play includes a YouTuber, an influencer and a meme machine. Sometimes total chaos ensues.
content: The new play “Circle Jerk” is a lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin
title: Voters favor Biden over Trump on almost all major issues, a new poll shows.
description: Voters favor Biden over Trump on almost all major issues, a New York Times/Siena College poll found.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. holds a nine-point lead over President Trump amid widespread public alarm about the trajectory of the coronavirus pandemic and demand among voters for large-scale government action to right the economy, according to a national poll of likely voters conducted by The New York Times and Siena College.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Talbot
title: A Bucket Bag Originally Intended to Carry Champagne
description: The latest iteration of Louis Vuitton’s NéoNoé design features smaller proportions and a multicolored patchwork of shearling.
content: The house of Louis Vuitton opened its doors in 1854 as a luggage and packing shop and quickly became known for its crafted canvas steamer trunks and wardrobe cases. Over the decades, they manufactured traveling goods for royals, fin de siècle explorers and their jet-setting clientele — and created custom carrying kits for everything from books and cigars to perfumes and polo gear. Perhaps their most famous special order, however, came in 1932, when Gaston-Louis Vuitton (the founder’s grandson) received a request from a champagne producer who wanted him to design a leather bag he could give as a gift to his clients. He had only two requirements: It should bear the weight of multiple bottles and stand the test of time. Gaston went to work, and soon the Noé was born. With its tapered rectangular base, the versatile bucket bag could fit five bottles of bubbly: four standing upright and one flipped upside down in the center. A drawstring closure prevented them from breaking or clanking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Farber
title: Spencer Davis, Whose Band Helped Power the Sound of the ’60s, Dies at 81
description: Hits like “Gimme Some Lovin’” and “I’m a Man” made the Spencer Davis Group, based in Britain, famous worldwide and launched the career of its lead singer, Steve Winwood.
content: Spencer Davis, the leader of a rock group under his name that had some of the most propulsive and enduring hits of the 1960s, including “Gimme Some Lovin’,” “I’m a Man” and “Keep On Running” — all sung not by him but by a teenage Steve Winwood — died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Trump describes hypothetical quid pro quo with Exxon. Exxon says: ‘It never happened.’
description: Shortly after President Trump said at a campaign rally that he could, hypothetically, call up the chief executive of Exxon Mobil and ask for a campaign contribution in return for granting political favors, the company took to Twitter to say that no such call had ever taken place.
content: Shortly after President Trump said at a campaign rally that he could, hypothetically, call up the chief executive of Exxon Mobil and ask for a campaign contribution in return for granting political favors, the company took to Twitter to say that no such call had ever taken place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deirdre Mask
title: The Organization System That Changed the World? It’s Thousands of Years Old
description: In “A Place for Everything,” Judith Flanders, a British social historian, traces the revolutionary history of alphabetical order.
content: A PLACE FOR EVERYTHING The Curious History of Alphabetical Order By Judith Flanders
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh and Lucy Tompkins
title: ‘It Has Hit Us With a Vengeance’: Virus Surges Again Across the United States
description: Unlike earlier outbreaks concentrated in the Northeast and South, the virus is simmering at a worrisome level in most regions.
content: Follow our live coverage of the coronavirus pandemic here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Davey Alba
title: Facing a Deluge of Misinformation, Colorado Takes the Offensive Against It
description: The state will combat false information on social media and even buy Google ads against it. But few states are following suit.
content: Like so many modern election sagas, it started with a tweet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Frenchette Opens a Bakery Nearby
description: The TriBeCa restaurant has taken over the former Arcade Bakery space for its new bakery, featuring breads made with uncommon grains like malted corn.
content: Last year, Roger Gural closed his esteemed Arcade Bakery in the lobby of a TriBeCa office building. The space has now been taken over by Riad Nasr and Lee Hanson, the owners of the nearby restaurant Frenchette. Their head baker, Peter Edris, formerly at Bourke Street Bakery, and Frenchette’s pastry chef, Michelle Palazzo, monitor the ovens to create baguettes and boules, most of them incorporating uncommon grains like malted corn, spelt and malted rye from River Valley Community Grains in Long Valley, N.J. Frenchette Bakery even has chocolate chip cookies made with buckwheat flour, along with croissants and the like. Its savory croissant is filled with egg, kimchi, greens and mortadella.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ayten Tartici
title: The Pious French Poet Who Palled Around With Picasso and Apollinaire
description: In “Max Jacob: A Life in Art and Letters,” Rosanna Warren retraces the colorful history of a now largely forgotten figure of French modernism who was surrounded by famous friends.
content: MAX JACOBA Life in Art and LettersBy Rosanna Warren
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: The Power of Latino Voters
description: Tuesday: “Let’s get rid of the notion of the sleeping giant.” Also: An update on California’s vaccine planning.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Jesse McKinley
title: No, New York Isn’t Putting New Jersey on the Quarantine List
description: The governor said he would not restrict travelers from New Jersey, Connecticut or Pennsylvania, despite virus spikes in those states.
content: The coronavirus has spiked in states that border New York, with the rates of new cases hitting a point that is supposed to trigger restrictions on travelers entering New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: A Supreme Court Split on Voting
description: A decision on Pennsylvania ballots has implications for the future: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: The Supreme Court issues a ruling with implications for Election Day, while Trump steps up his attacks on Fauci. It’s Tuesday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliana Kim
title: What to Know About N.Y.’s Plastic Bag Ban
description: After months of delays and a lawsuit, the statewide ban on the single-use bags is being enforced. Paper bags are now 5 cents.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Case(s) Against Big Tech
description: Partisan infighting may take pressure off the tech giants.
content: On Nov. 17 and 18, DealBook opens its doors to our first Online Summit. Join us as we welcome consequential newsmakers in business, policy and culture to explore the pivotal questions of the moment — and the future. Watch from anywhere in the world, free of charge. Register now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Stock buybacks are about to get more complicated.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission recently settled a case that may have major implications for publicly traded companies, notes today’s DealBook newsletter. The regulator imposed a fine over a stock buyback by the energy company Andeavor, introducing an unexpected accounting wrinkle to the repurchase process that experts say companies have probably not considered before.
content: The Securities and Exchange Commission recently settled a case that may have major implications for publicly traded companies, notes today’s DealBook newsletter. The regulator imposed a fine over a stock buyback by the energy company Andeavor, introducing an unexpected accounting wrinkle to the repurchase process that experts say companies have probably not considered before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: Breonna Taylor Grand Juror Says Homicide Charges Were Not Presented
description: A judge gave grand jurors in the case permission to speak publicly, a rare move that immediately led one juror to speak out.
content: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — A Kentucky judge on Tuesday granted grand jurors in the Breonna Taylor case permission to speak publicly, a rare move that immediately led one juror to assert that prosecutors had not given the panel the opportunity to bring homicide charges in the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Jeff Bridges Says He Has Lymphoma
description: The actor said on Monday that he had started treatment and that his prognosis was “good.”
content: Jeff Bridges, the actor known for his roles as Bad Blake in “Crazy Heart” and The Dude in “The Big Lebowski,” announced on Monday that he has lymphoma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Frances Robles
title: Will Florida, the Recount State, Be Ready for the Election?
description: Elections supervisors say the hard-earned lessons of the 2000 presidential recount and other messes have taught them well. But the challenges are already apparent.
content: MIAMI — Most states have the occasional problems running their elections. Not Florida. Florida has debacles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: Google Up Against Laws That Thwarted Microsoft (and Others Since 1890)
description: The Justice Department’s antitrust case points to restrictive contracts, a focus that a professor said “is as old as the Sherman Act.”
content: Two weeks ago, House lawmakers concluded a 16-month investigation into Amazon, Apple, Google and Facebook and called for sweeping changes to curb their market power. The lawmakers’ verdict: Traditional antitrust laws aren’t up to the challenge, and the laws need their biggest overhaul in more than 40 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lloyd Kramer and Scott Chestnut
title: A Priest Who Left the Church for Love
description: They wanted to marry. But he’d taken a vow of celibacy.
content: Terence Netter and Therese Franzese fell in love in New York City in the 1960s. She was an assistant to Rudolf Bing, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera. He was an accomplished painter and Jesuit priest. They sought to marry and dreamed the Catholic Church would embrace a married priesthood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: As Britain edges toward lockdowns, long-held grievances flare up.
description: Britain’s desperate attempt to curb a second wave of the coronavirus has exposed multiple fractures in its politics and society, but perhaps none as jagged as that between Prime Minister Boris Johnson and the mayor of Greater Manchester, the country’s second-largest urban area.
content: Britain’s desperate attempt to curb a second wave of the coronavirus has exposed multiple fractures in its politics and society, but perhaps none as jagged as that between Prime Minister Boris Johnson and the mayor of Greater Manchester, the country’s second-largest urban area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Anthony Chisholm Dies at 77; Acclaimed in August Wilson Roles
description: He appeared in numerous productions of Wilson’s Pittsburgh Cycle plays, including four on Broadway.
content: Anthony Chisholm, an actor who was among the foremost interpreters of August Wilson, appearing in dozens of productions of that playwright’s works, both on Broadway and in leading regional theaters, died on Friday at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shola Lawal
title: Nigerian Forces Fire on Protesters
description: The toll was unclear, but witnesses said several people were shot during  demonstrations against police brutality in Lagos. The governor said “miscreants” had hijacked mostly peaceful protests.
content: LAGOS, Nigeria — Nigerian security forces opened fire Tuesday night at a demonstration in Lagos against police brutality, hitting several people according to witnesses, in a major escalation of the unrest that has gripped the country for two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: I Used a Sperm Donor. Should I Introduce My Daughter to Her Half Siblings?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to make your donor’s numerous offspring part of your child’s family — and more.
content: I am a single mother by choice. My baby, now 10 months old, was conceived using an “open ID” donor from a sperm bank, which means that when my daughter turns 18, she can contact the donor via the sperm bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bailey Berg
title: Six Enormous Hot-Dog-Shaped Vehicles Travel America, Spreading Only Brand Awareness and Joy
description: A pandemic cannot stop either marketing or human emotions.
content: “It was the only job I applied to,” Molly Swindall said. She grew up outside Atlanta and recently finished a master’s degree in security and intelligence in, and sponsored by, the European Union. “I put all my eggs in that basket. It was my dream job.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: The Blood-Broth Noodles at Pata Paplean Are Elusive No More
description: A bar in Elmhurst that sold sought-after bowls of Thai noodles for a few hours each weekend now relies on them full time to ride out the pandemic.
content: Before the pandemic, Pata Paplean’s nam tok boat noodles would slosh briefly into view each Saturday around noon and stay there until 5 p.m., all times being highly approximate. The next afternoon the noodles would return to the bar. Then they would disappear until the following weekend, when they would come back for another ten-hour manifestation. If you wanted a bowl, you almost had to set an alarm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Watergate Led to Reforms. Now, Would-Be Reformers Believe, So Will Trump.
description: Among the possibilities are proposals developed by a Justice Department official from the Bush administration and a White House counsel under President Barack Obama.
content: WASHINGTON — After the twin traumas of the Vietnam War and the Watergate scandal came a period of change in the nation’s capital. The system set about reinventing itself to realign the balance of power, establish new guardrails for those in high office and try to enforce greater accountability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Tompkins
title: To avoid quarantining students, a school district tries moving them around every 15 minutes.
description: To reduce the number of students sent home to quarantine after exposure to the coronavirus, the Billings Public Schools, the largest school district in Montana, came up with an idea that has public health experts shaking their heads: Reshuffling students in the classroom four times an hour.
content: To reduce the number of students sent home to quarantine after exposure to the coronavirus, the Billings Public Schools, the largest school district in Montana, came up with an idea that has public health experts shaking their heads: Reshuffling students in the classroom four times an hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Nicholas Fandos
title: McConnell Moves to Head Off Stimulus Deal as Pelosi Reports Progress
description: The top Senate Republican told colleagues that he had advised the White House against striking a pre-election deal with Democrats to deliver pandemic aid, fearing political repercussions.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, privately told Republican senators on Tuesday that he had warned the White House not to strike a pre-election deal with Speaker Nancy Pelosi on a new round of stimulus, moving to head off an agreement that President Trump has demanded but most in his party oppose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: San Francisco Takes Action on Racial Profiling in 911 Calls
description: The legislation has an eye-catching acronym, CAREN, and would allow lawsuits against people who are motivated by bias when calling the police.
content: The San Francisco board of supervisors on Tuesday unanimously approved legislation aimed at cracking down on frivolous calls to 911 against people of color, a move that will make it the latest city to enact an ordinance against racist calls to the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: N.Y. Accuses Christian Group of Misleading Consumers on Health Coverage
description: Regulators say a major group is misrepresenting cost-sharing plans, saddling people with unpaid medical bills.
content: New York State accused a major Christian group on Tuesday of deceiving customers by illegally offering health insurance to as many as 40,000 residents since 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: In Arizona, Trump dismisses the virus and again claims Democrats will ‘destroy’ the suburbs.
description: President Trump told voters in Arizona that Americans are “getting tired of the pandemic” and accused the news media of exaggerating the crisis, as he sought to make up ground in a traditionally Republican state where the virus is making a comeback.
content: President Trump told voters in Arizona that Americans are “getting tired of the pandemic” and accused the news media of exaggerating the crisis, as he sought to make up ground in a traditionally Republican state where the virus is making a comeback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
title: Emiratis Land in Israel, Firming New Ties and Angering Palestinians
description: In the first official U.A.E. visit to Israel since the countries normalized relations, they agreed to ease travel and upgrade West Bank checkpoints. Palestinians called it tacit assent to Israeli occupation.
content: JERUSALEM — Diplomats from the United Arab Emirates on Tuesday made their first official trip to Israel since the countries normalized relations in August, and the two sides signed pacts deepening their ties, including allowing their citizens to travel from one country to the other without visas — Israel’s first such waiver with an Arab state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Rebecca Cryer, 73, Tribal Judge and Oklahoma City Bomb Survivor, Dies
description: Judge Cryer, who traced her ancestry to the Pottawatamie people, traveled the country to assist poorly funded native courts. She died of the coronavirus.
content: They set flags to half-staff across the Choctaw Nation in Oklahoma after the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg in September — and lowered them again 11 days later to honor Rebecca Cryer, a tribal judge who led a purposeful, parallel life in the law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: France Crackdown, Manchester Restrictions, Nazca Lines Cat: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: A brutal killing in France prompts a swift official response.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas May
title: Whispers of an Italian-Jewish Past Fill a Composer’s Music
description: Yotam Haber’s “Estro Poetico-Armonico III” combines live singing with archival recordings of cantors.
content: Since early in his career, Yotam Haber has grappled with what it means to be a contemporary Jewish composer. The tentative answers offered by his music — full of allusions, distortion and whispers of the past — suggest that the grappling itself is a vital part of that identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Is Your Favorite Memory of PBS?
description: The Public Broadcasting Service is celebrating its 50th birthday. Which shows and characters have made their mark on your life?
content: “Sesame Street.” “Arthur.” “Downton Abbey.” “Antiques Roadshow.” Cookie Monster. Barney. Daniel Tiger. Dora the Explorer. Nature shows. Documentaries and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Parul Sehgal
title: Martin Amis Offers the ‘Inside Story’ of His Relationships With Three Famous Writers
description: Amis’s new book is a “novelized autobiography” in which he writes warmly and familiarly about Philip Larkin, Saul Bellow and Christopher Hitchens.
content: About 20 years ago, Martin Amis — the writer with the most pronounced daddy issues this side of Sylvia Plath — received a letter from an especially harrowing ex-girlfriend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Isabella Kwai
title: 1,300 Prisoners Escape From Congo Jail After an Attack Claimed by ISIS
description: Local officials blamed an Islamist militant group for the assault on the prison and a nearby military camp in the northeastern part of the country.
content: At least 1,300 prisoners escaped from a jail in the Democratic Republic of Congo early on Tuesday, the United Nations said, after an armed assault for which the Islamic State has claimed responsibility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Revving Engines
description: What story does this video inspire for you?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Did Bayern Complete Its Rebuild While No One Noticed?
description: Bayern’s second treble arrived seven years after its first. But those who have long suggested its veteran team needed rejuvenation might be surprised to learn the job is already done.
content: Hansi Flick did not see the parallel. This spring, like millions of others, he found himself absorbed by “The Last Dance,” the story of how, seven years after its first triumph, that great generation of the Chicago Bulls — Jordan, Pippen and a fluid supporting cast — found the drive, hunger and inspiration to conquer the world one last time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Presidential Elections May Be Bad for Your Health
description: The incidence of heart attacks and strokes rise around election time, researchers report.
content: The stress of presidential elections may increase the incidence of heart attacks and strokes, researchers report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic and Will Dudding
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: “No room for complacency,” Modi says.
content: In a televised address, Prime Minister Narendra Modi urged Indians to keep their guard up as more than a billion people get ready to celebrate Diwali and other major holidays. The authorities are worried about the spread of the coronavirus from people packing together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Facebook and Twitter Are Still Tinkering With Democracy
description: Social media companies are debuting strategies to prevent a repeat of the 2016 election. They may be backfiring.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: moribund
description: This word has appeared in 53 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: The Pandemic’s Real Toll? 300,000 Deaths, and It’s Not Just From the Coronavirus
description: A C.D.C. analysis finds that overall death rates have risen, particularly among young adults and people of color.
content: The coronavirus pandemic caused nearly 300,000 deaths in the United States through early October, federal researchers said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: A TV Station’s Mistake Highlights Fears of Election Night Misinformation
description: A graphic on an evening news broadcast in Arkansas showed President Trump winning the state three weeks before Election Day.
content: WASHINGTON — When some viewers in Arkansas tuned in to their local television news station last week, they found a surprising report: President Trump had defeated Joseph R. Biden Jr. in the state — three weeks before Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Signe Brewster
title: It’s Time to Try Virtual Reality. Here’s Where to Start.
description: Running out of fun things to do at home? The new generation of VR headsets is surprisingly approachable, with games for players of all ages.
content: If ever there were a year to try games that can drop you into an alternate reality, 2020 would be it. As the coronavirus pandemic restricts our travel and the never-ending news cycle weighs on our minds, a virtual reality headset can provide some relief, escape and distraction (at least for a little bit) from actual reality. It’s one of the best ways to leave home from the comfort of your home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Rev. John Vakulskas Dies at 76; Carnivals Were His Parish
description: He ministered to generations of carnival workers, and his work was recognized by popes. He died of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Michigan Woman Found Alive at Funeral Home Dies 8 Weeks Later
description: Timesha Beauchamp, 20, was declared dead in August, only to be found alive hours later at a funeral home near Detroit. She died on Sunday.
content: A young Michigan woman who was pronounced dead in August, only to be found alive at a funeral home hours later, has died, her family’s lawyer said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Big donors play a key, and quiet, role in the Biden campaign.
description: One evening last month, about 100,000 people watched and donated to a virtual fund-raiser for the Biden campaign featuring Hillary Clinton, Senator Kamala Harris, and two actors who portrayed them on “Saturday Night Live,” Amy Poehler and Maya Rudolph. By all accounts, the small-donor event was a success: It raised $4.4 million.
content: One evening last month, about 100,000 people watched and donated to a virtual fund-raiser for the Biden campaign featuring Hillary Clinton, Senator Kamala Harris, and two actors who portrayed them on “Saturday Night Live,” Amy Poehler and Maya Rudolph. By all accounts, the small-donor event was a success: It raised $4.4 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Tie Gives Pennsylvania More Time to Tally Some Votes
description: A 4-to-4 tie let stand a ruling from Pennsylvania’s highest court that had extended the deadline for counting some mailed ballots by three days, citing the pandemic and postal delays.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday let stand a ruling by Pennsylvania’s highest court that allowed election officials to count some mailed ballots received up to three days after Election Day. The state is a key battleground in the presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Davey Alba
title: Colorado is fighting back against election misinformation.
description: Bracing for a deluge of misinformation as Election Day draws closer, Colorado is stepping up its initiative to prevent deceptive tweets, doctored videos and other forms of false material from undermining elections in the state.
content: Bracing for a deluge of misinformation as Election Day draws closer, Colorado is stepping up its initiative to prevent deceptive tweets, doctored videos and other forms of false material from undermining elections in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: Modi Warns India to Keep Its Guard Up as Hindu Festival Season Nears
description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi told his nation that the coronavirus situation in India was stable, but that “we must not let it deteriorate.”
content: NEW DELHI — In a televised address Tuesday night, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India urged his countrymen to tighten up their vigilance against the coronavirus as the Hindu festival season approaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: To Test Virus Vaccines, U.K. Study Will Intentionally Infect Volunteers
description: The hotly contested strategy of deliberate exposure, known as a human challenge trial, could speed up the process of identifying effective coronavirus vaccines.
content: LONDON — Scientists at Imperial College London plan to deliberately infect volunteers with the coronavirus early next year, launching the world’s first effort to study how vaccinated people respond to being intentionally exposed to the virus and opening up a new, uncertain path to identifying an effective vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Luke Broadwater
title: Stocks rise in the U.S. ahead of Tuesday’s deadline that Pelosi set for stimulus talks.
description: U.S. stocks rose on Tuesday, the day Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California set as a deadline for a compromise stimulus deal that could be considered before the election. The S&P 500 was up nearly half a percent in early trading, after falling 1.6 percent on Monday.
content: U.S. stocks rose on Tuesday, the day Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California set as a deadline for a compromise stimulus deal that could be considered before the election. The S&P 500 was up nearly half a percent in early trading, after falling 1.6 percent on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba and Jack Nicas
title: Here Are the Hundreds of Sites in a Pay-to-Play Local News Network
description: We are publishing the full list so readers can see whether the sites target their area.
content: A fast-growing network of nearly 1,300 websites is filling a void left by vanishing local newspapers across the country. But many of their stories are ordered up by conservative political groups and corporate P.R. firms, a Times investigation found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Trump Is Giving Up
description: Against both the coronavirus and Joe Biden, the president’s strategy increasingly accepts defeat.
content: Donald Trump can still win the 2020 presidential election; something that has a 10 percent or 15 percent chance of happening can certainly transpire. But even more than in 2016, if the president wins this time, we will have to attribute his victory to the workings of divine providence (don’t worry, I have that column pre-written), because what we’re watching is an incumbent doing everything in his power to run up his own margin of defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin
title: Voters Prefer Biden Over Trump on Almost All Major Issues, Poll Shows
description: Joe Biden leads President Trump, 50 percent to 41 percent, a New York Times/Siena College poll shows, with voters favoring him by wide margins on the coronavirus and law and order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth
title: As Election Nears, Government and Tech Firms Push Back on Russia (and Trump)
description: The goal is to disrupt Russia’s well-honed information-warfare systems, whether they are poised to hack election systems or influence the minds of voters.
content: Over the past two weeks, United States Cyber Command and a group of companies led by Microsoft have engaged in an aggressive campaign against a suspected Russian network that they feared could hold election systems hostage come November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: N.T.S.B. Says Delays Made California Boat Fire More Deadly
description: The fire aboard the Conception scuba dive boat killed 34 people last year.
content: The lack of a required night patrol aboard a scuba dive boat delayed the response to a fire that killed 34 people last year, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The Encroachment of the Unsayable
description: Our compromised liberalism has left a generation of writers weighing their words in fear.
content: In January, in what now seems like a bygone age, the writer George Packer delivered a memorable speech, “The Enemies of Writing,” for the honor of winning the Hitchens Prize. “Why is a career like that of Christopher Hitchens not only unlikely but almost unimaginable?” Packer asked. “Put another way: Why is the current atmosphere inhospitable to it? What are the enemies of writing today?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Hamblin
title: Yes, Books Were Bound in Human Skin. An Intrepid Librarian Finds the Proof.
description: “Dark Archives,” by Megan Rosenbloom, a librarian at U.C.L.A., traces the history of the controversial practice and considers what we should do with such books today.
content: DARK ARCHIVESA Librarian’s Investigation Into the Science and History of Books Bound in Human SkinBy Megan Rosenbloom
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Gray
title: Some Democrats fear losing college students’ votes because of widespread remote learning.
description: With college campuses quiet as universities adopted online instruction to help stop the spread of coronavirus, a new political wrinkle came with it: Some House candidates, typically Democrats, can usually count on support from students living on college campuses in their districts — but many of those students are now living back home.
content: With college campuses quiet as universities adopted online instruction to help stop the spread of coronavirus, a new political wrinkle came with it: Some House candidates, typically Democrats, can usually count on support from students living on college campuses in their districts — but many of those students are now living back home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judge John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Fall A.C. Removal
description: Should your wife have taken the air-conditioner out of the window when there were still hot days to come?
content: We live in New England, and my wife likes to take the air-conditioner out of the window at the first sign of fall. This bugs me, especially as I now often work from home. She took out the A.C. today, but this week it’s going to be 85 degrees. Please order my wife not to remove the A.C. unit so early.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Blockbuster Trade Has Been Good for Both Sides
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 20, 2020.
content: “I’m always chasing greatness. I feel like we’re nowhere close to where we can be.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yanna Krupnikov and John Barry Ryan
title: The Real Divide in America Is Between Political Junkies and Everyone Else
description: Most Americans view politics as two camps bickering endlessly and fruitlessly over unimportant issues.
content: The common view of American politics today is of a clamorous divide between Democrats and Republicans, an unyielding, inevitable clash of harsh partisan polarization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: A Democratic Super PAC Surge Helps Biden Expand His Map
description: Enormous advertising buys announced in the last month of the campaign amount to a huge advantage for Joe Biden, allowing him to fight in long-shot states like Texas.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Nick Corasaniti, your host on Tuesdays for our coverage of all things media and messaging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: What Is Happening With the Antitrust Suit Against Google?
description: The suit is the first antitrust action against the company to result from investigations by American regulators.
content: The Justice Department sued Google on Tuesday, accusing the company of illegally abusing its dominance in internet search in ways that harm competitors and consumers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Haimerl
title: In one Montana town, mask rules vary by the business.
description: In a small business district in Montana, owners are trying to navigate conflicting directives on mask-wearing to combat the spread of the coronavirus — and it’s taken them into some emotional territory.
content: In a small business district in Montana, owners are trying to navigate conflicting directives on mask-wearing to combat the spread of the coronavirus — and it’s taken them into some emotional territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Andrew Higgins
title: U.S. and Russia Appear to Edge Toward Extension of Nuclear Treaty
description: Russia proposed that the two countries make a “political obligation” to freeze their existing arsenals of warheads for one year.
content: The United States and Russia on Tuesday appeared to be edging toward a short-term extension of the main arms control treaty limiting the size of the two nations’ nuclear arsenals, after Russia agreed to add a “political obligation” that would freeze its stockpile of nuclear warheads for a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phillip Atiba Goff
title: The Dystopian Police State the Trump Administration Wants
description: Law enforcement’s problems could get even worse.
content: Jenée Desmond-Harris, a staff editor in Opinion, wrote about this essay in today’s Opinion Today newsletter. You can read it here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Should a Neutral-Site World Series Become Baseball’s New Normal?
description: Scott Boras, the sport’s most powerful agent, thinks M.L.B.’s marquee event deserves more pageantry, which isn’t easy to produce quickly in a two-city Series.
content: ARLINGTON, Texas — The Los Angeles Dodgers and the Tampa Bay Rays gathered at Globe Life Field here Tuesday for the first game of the World Series, the 116th in history and the first at a neutral site. The Dodgers, who cruised to an 8-3 win, were the home team, more than 1,200 miles from their home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: In China, the Formidable Prosecutor Turned Lonely Rights Defender
description: After sheltering a prominent dissident, Yang Bin, a former prosecutor, is now under the scrutiny of the police. But she has no regrets.
content: Yang Bin was at home when two dozen Chinese police surrounded her house and entered, searching for the man she had recently taken in as a houseguest. Filing in quickly, the officers found their suspect upstairs and arrested him, ending a weekslong manhunt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Emily Cochrane
title: As McConnell advises White House against pre-election stimulus deal, Pelosi and Mnuchin make headway in talks.
description: "Hopefully, by the end of the day today, we’ll know where we all are,” Speaker Nancy Pelosi said in a television interview.
content: Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky and the majority leader, told Republican senators privately on Tuesday that he has advised the White House not to strike a deal with Speaker Nancy Pelosi on a new stimulus bill before Election Day, cautioning against reaching an agreement that most in the party cannot accept.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Weiner
title: Welcome to Life in the Swing State of Pennsylvania
description: I’m drowning in campaign lit and freaking out about my mail-in ballot.
content: PHILADELPHIA — On Tuesday afternoon, it was Karla texting my husband. On Saturday, it was Carin and Britney. Mara got in touch the next day. Susan and Debra reached out last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hard
title: Line holders are paid to wait all night outside a motor vehicle office.
description: In a New Jersey suburb, a woman sets up a tent around 8 p.m. outside a state Motor Vehicle Commission office. She will spend the night there, accompanied by her 4-year-old son, until just before the office opens at 8 a.m. The woman, Sumbal Nadeem, doesn’t need a driver’s license or anything else from the agency.
content: In a New Jersey suburb, a woman sets up a tent around 8 p.m. outside a state Motor Vehicle Commission office. She will spend the night there, accompanied by her 4-year-old son, until just before the office opens at 8 a.m. The woman, Sumbal Nadeem, doesn’t need a driver’s license or anything else from the agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Apple iPhone 12 Review: Superfast Speed, if You Can Find It
description: The new iPhone has an improved design, but it’s undermined by the wireless industry’s messy rollout of ultrafast 5G networks.
content: I started this iPhone review in the most peculiar way: by opening a map to find out where I could test it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
title: E.U. Tells Cyprus and Malta to Abandon ‘Golden Passports’
description: The two countries have raised billions of euros by selling thousands of coveted travel documents, even in some cases granting citizenship to foreigners fleeing arrest warrants.
content: BRUSSELS — Cyprus and Malta will face European Union penalties if they do not abandon lucrative programs that sell “golden passports” to foreigners, the bloc says, a long-anticipated crackdown on a practice that in certain cases furnished foreigners — some accused of crimes in their home countries — with travel documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: The Justice Dept.’s Lawsuit Against Google: Too Little, Too Late
description: The time to do anything substantive about the overwhelming power of the giant tech companies passed very long ago.
content: It might seem a Silicon Valley cliché, but it was a garage — a pretty dumpy one for those who got to visit it just over two decades ago — that served as the birthplace of what the U.S. government today is calling a crippler of competition, a reducer of consumer choice and a stifler of innovation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Haimerl
title: Mask mandate? In a Montana town, it ‘puts us at odds with customers.’
description: This summer, Governor Steve Bullock of Montana mandated face coverings in public spaces to combat a spike in Covid-19 cases. But the sheriff in the town of Hamilton, backed up by the Ravalli County commissioners, elected not to enforce the order, saying individual rights took priority.
content: This summer, Governor Steve Bullock of Montana mandated face coverings in public spaces to combat a spike in Covid-19 cases. But the sheriff in the town of Hamilton, backed up by the Ravalli County commissioners, elected not to enforce the order, saying individual rights took priority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenée Desmond-Harris
title: Opinion Today: Trump’s Blueprint for Dystopian Policing
description: If this expert is worried, you should be too.
content: This article was originally published in our Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hard
title: Line Holders Are Paid to Wait All Night Outside Motor Vehicle Offices
description: A huge backlog at the New Jersey Motor Vehicle Commission has spawned a new gig worker.
content: In a New Jersey suburb, a woman sets up a tent around 8 p.m. outside a state Motor Vehicle Commission office. She will spend the night there, accompanied by her 4-year-old son, until just before the office opens at 8 a.m. The woman, Sumbal Nadeem, doesn’t need a driver’s license or anything else from the agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Michael Crowley
title: Trump Calls on Barr to ‘Act’ Against Biden Before Election
description: The president is increasingly fixated on seeing criminal action against his political opponents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: An Almost-Lake House in Texas, Renovated for Work and Art
description: For a tech investor and a radiologist who collects art, having a multifunctional house was even more important than finding one directly on a lake.
content: In 2015, when Dacia and Lanham Napier were touring Austin, Texas, with a real estate agent, they weren’t looking for a home — they were searching for office space in the tech-centric city for Mr. Napier, the chief executive of the investment firm BuildGroup and the former chief executive of Rackspace Technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Sipher
title: The Intelligence Director Who Is Undermining Trust and Truth
description: John Ratcliffe is breaking norms, which could weaken our defenses.
content: It’s quite an accomplishment, but in only five months, the director of national intelligence, John Ratcliffe, has already put himself in the running to be considered among the most destructive intelligence officials in U.S. history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: City Winery Opens in Hudson River Park
description: A counter-service spot from Make It Nice alumni, delivery-only dumplings and more restaurant news.
content: In the midst of the pandemic, it pays to have lots of space. Michael Dorf, the owner of City Winery, a group of wine, food and music spaces, has just such a location: 32,000 square feet on a renovated Hudson River pier that can accommodate 200 socially distanced indoor seats at the required 25 percent capacity. There are also 70 seats outdoors. City Winery started in 2008 in Hudson Square, but it had to move after its block was bought by Disney in 2018. There are now full locations in seven cities across the country, not including another four satellite venues, plus one in the Hudson Valley. No stranger to challenges, Mr. Dorf said he started the City Winery brand in a major economic downturn, and now, “I am launching our new flagship during a global pandemic.” Planned music events, for which City Winery is known, have yet to be permitted. There’s a cellar with 1,200 bottles and a Mediterranean menu from the chef Robert Hamburg that includes pizza and assorted flatbreads. Like its original location, the new City Winery has a winemaking facility, storage tanks and barrels. There are a dozen wines on tap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Armenia and Azerbaijan: The Conflict Explained’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the history of the Nagorno-Karabakh region and why experts say the fighting this time is different.
content: Featured Article: “Armenia and Azerbaijan: The Conflict Explained” by Andrew E. Kramer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Goldman Sachs Is Said to Admit Mistakes in 1MDB Scandal
description: A foreign subsidiary of the Wall Street giant will plead guilty under an agreement with the Justice Department, according to a person familiar with the deal.
content: An Asian subsidiary of Goldman Sachs will plead guilty to charges in the United States to resolve a foreign corruption and bribery case over the looting of billions of dollars from a Malaysian sovereign wealth fund, according to a person familiar with the agreement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Spanish Judge Releases a Fugitive Italian Mafia Suspect
description: A court spokesman said the judge had not been aware of accusations linking the fugitive to organized crime.
content: MADRID — A Spanish judge has released a fugitive Italian organized-crime suspect just days after his arrest, and a court spokesman said on Tuesday that the judge was unaware the man had been identified as a leading figure in a powerful criminal operation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophia June
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $1.83 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Elliott Broidy Pleads Guilty in Foreign Lobbying Case
description: A former fund-raiser for President Trump admitted to a role in a covert campaign to influence the administration on behalf of Chinese and Malaysian interests.
content: WASHINGTON — Elliott Broidy, a former top fund-raiser for President Trump, pleaded guilty on Tuesday to conspiring to violate foreign lobbying laws as part of a covert campaign to influence the administration on behalf of Chinese and Malaysian interests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martin Selsoe Sorensen and Megan Specia
title: Peter Madsen, Who Killed Kim Wall in a Submarine, Briefly Escapes Prison
description: Mr. Madsen fled the Herstedvester Prison near Copenhagen after threatening staff and wearing a fake explosive belt. He was detained a short time later, the police said.
content: ODENSE, Denmark — Armed with what the police believe was a fake gun and a mock explosive belt, Peter Madsen ran for the gates at the prison outside Copenhagen where he was serving a life sentence for killing the journalist Kim Wall on his homemade submarine three years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becca Rothfeld
title: Celebrating Strange Faces, Gorgeous Sentences and Circular Prose
description: Brilliant new essay collections from Namwali Serpell, Brian Dillon and Daniel Mendelsohn.
content: THREE RINGS A Tale of Exile, Narrative, and FateBy Daniel Mendelsohn116 pp. University of Virginia. $19.95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Rush Limbaugh Says His Lung Cancer Is ‘Going in the Wrong Direction’
description: The radio host, who announced in February that he had lung cancer, told his listeners that there was “some progression” of cancer despite treatment.
content: Rush Limbaugh, the conservative talk radio host, said on his show on Monday that his lung cancer had grown worse and was “going in the wrong direction” despite treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sundas Hashmi
title: My Brother Died of Brain Cancer. 20 Years Later, I Had It, Too.
description: I was told it didn’t run in families. Was it just chance?
content: It was the afternoon of Jan. 31. I was preparing for a dinner party and adding final touches to my cheese platter when everything suddenly went dark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: The pandemic has pushed some Silicon Valley start-ups back into the garage.
description: Designing and creating new technology — never an easy task — has become far more difficult in the pandemic.
content: Designing and creating new technology — never an easy task — has become far more difficult in the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Taunts Lesley Stahl of ‘60 Minutes’ After Cutting Off Interview
description: Two weeks from Election Day, the president picked a fight with the country’s most popular television news program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Cohen
title: In Don DeLillo’s New Novel, Technology Is Dead. Civilization Might Be, Too.
description: “The Silence” invites readers to consider whether the connected life has left us more disconnected than ever.
content: THE SILENCEBy Don DeLillo
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon and Andy Newman
title: In deep-blue New York City, a gated beachfront haven where Trump flags fly.
description: Donald J. Trump’s hometown, New York City, has not exactly been hospitable to him as a politician. In the 2016 election, Hillary Clinton outpolled him here more than four to one.
content: Donald J. Trump’s hometown, New York City, has not exactly been hospitable to him as a politician. In the 2016 election, Hillary Clinton outpolled him here more than four to one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: ‘It’s a New Day’: Sudan Exults in Move to Take It Off List of Terror States
description: President Trump said on Monday that the U.S. plans to lift Sudan’s 27-year designation as a state sponsor of terrorism, enabling Sudan to access international financial networks.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Sudanese people and their government officials are celebrating the news that after 27 years the United States plans to remove the country from its list of state sponsors of terrorism — a move that could help Sudan revive its ailing economy and bolster its transition to democratic rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: Trump’s Antibody ‘Cure’ Will Be in Short Supply
description: All the weak points of American health care — testing delays, communication breakdowns, inequity — are working against this potential treatment.
content: Nearly two weeks ago, President Trump told Americans that they would soon be getting an antibody treatment that he had promoted, without evidence, as a “cure” for the coronavirus. This weekend, as the country braced for another major wave of coronavirus infections, Mr. Trump’s health secretary promised such therapies were just around the corner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: Kamala Harris, Mass Incarceration and Me
description: Many progressives mistrust her for her past as a prosecutor. As an ex-convict — and also the son of a crime victim — I can tell you it’s not that simple.
content: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Anxiously Reads the Latest Polls
description: The “Late Show” host tossed some table salt and knocked on wood so as not to jinx Biden, who currently leads the president by 10 points in the polls.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Yancy
title: How Should an Atheist Think About Death?
description: The philosopher Todd May is an atheist who rejects the supernatural, but not the people who believe in it.
content: In five previous interviews in this series we’ve explored the Buddhist, Jain, Taoist, Jewish and Christian views on death and the afterlife. But what about those without any religious faith or belief in God? Why not, some readers have asked, interview an atheist? So we did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: With Black Artists’ Input, One Gallery Is ‘Starting to Look Different’
description: The Los Angeles dealer David Kordansky is using this moment to get more serious about helping and hiring people “left out of the conversation.”
content: LOS ANGELES — David Kordansky keeps one of Bob Weir’s guitars and Jerry Garcia’s amplifiers in the office of his gallery here in Mid-City. Love of the Grateful Dead, says the artist Mary Weatherford, helps explain Mr. Kordansky’s approach to being an art dealer. “The Grateful Dead is how Kordansky thinks,” she said. “There is a structure, but within the structure is improvisation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Trump and Biden Will Be Muted for Parts of Their Next Debate
description: In an unusual move meant to avoid interruptions like those that marred the first debate, the organizers said they would turn off each candidate’s audio feed while his rival had the floor.
content: [Read our live coverage of the final presidential debate between Trump and Biden.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: After 2 Hurricanes, Lake Charles Fears Its Cries for Help Have Gone Unheard
description: The city was shredded by Hurricanes Laura and Delta. But the needs of Lake Charles have been overlooked in a year of disaster and unrest.
content: LAKE CHARLES, La. — That first drive through Lake Charles after Hurricane Laura had been a gut punch. Trinette Thomas felt a barrage of surprise and despair as she strained to absorb the destruction surrounding her and imagine the lengths it would take to stagger back. Then, another storm hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Karen Cetinkaya
title: Google, Early Voting, World Series: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: ’Tis the Season for Toilet Paper Ornaments
description: Holiday décor vendors are leaning into the grief, anxiety and nihilism of this year.
content: If there’s one thing we could all use in 2020, it’s something to look forward to. Which could be why holiday decorating has gone into turbo mode this year: Elaborate Halloween tableaus lit up yards in August, and Christmas and Hanukkah decorations started popping up in July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Gray
title: College Students Aren’t on Campus. Their Missing Votes Could Make a Difference.
description: Some House candidates, typically Democrats, can usually count on support from students living on college campuses, but many of those students are now living back home.
content: EAST LANSING, Mich. — The air still became crisper, and the leaves still changed from green to gold. But many college towns looked a lot different this fall, their campuses quiet as universities adopted online instruction to help stop the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: It’s Google’s World. We Just Live in It.
description: Googling something was all we once did with Google. Now we spend hours a day using its maps, videos, security cameras, email, smartphones and more.
content: About 20 years ago, I typed Google.com into my web browser for the first time. It loaded a search bar and buttons. I punched in “D.M.V. sample test,” scrolled through the results and clicked on a site.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pauline W. Chen, M.D
title: Where Have All the Hospital Patients Gone?
description: Except in areas where Covid is surging, there are still no lines of patients in the hospital halls.
content: Weathered, wiry and in his early 60s, the man stumbled into clinic, trailing cigarette smoke and clutching his chest. Over the previous week, he had had fleeting episodes of chest pressure but stayed away from the hospital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: How ‘Spygate’ Attacks Fizzled
description: The baseless espionage narrative, which fueled right-wing conspiracy theories for years, has quietly faded from view.
content: For years, it was the subject of countless Fox News segments, talk radio rants, and viral right-wing tweets and Facebook posts. It spawned congressional hearings, Justice Department investigations, and investigations of those investigations. President Trump called it “the biggest political crime in the history of our country,” and suggested that its perpetrators deserved 50-year prison sentences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor and Neil Vigdor
title: A Memphis poll worker was fired for turning away voters wearing ‘Black Lives Matter’ shirts.
description: A poll worker in Memphis was fired last week after he improperly turned away several voters wearing T-shirts that said “Black Lives Matter” and “I Can’t Breathe,” a local election official said.
content: A poll worker in Memphis was fired last week after he improperly turned away several voters wearing T-shirts that said “Black Lives Matter” and “I Can’t Breathe,” a local election official said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Stewart and Todd Heisler
title: 1.5 million New Yorkers can’t afford food. Pantries are their lifeline.
description: As the pandemic settled into New York City, hunger drove tens of thousands of residents into food pantry lines, many for the first time. An estimated 1.5 million people cannot afford food.
content: As the pandemic settled into New York City, hunger drove tens of thousands of residents into food pantry lines, many for the first time. An estimated 1.5 million people cannot afford food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike McIntire, Russ Buettner and Susanne Craig
title: Trump Records Shed New Light on Chinese Business Pursuits
description: As he raises questions about his opponent’s standing with China, President Trump’s taxes reveal details about his own activities there, including a previously unknown bank account.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Seeking Solar System’s Secrets, NASA’s OSIRIS-REX Mission Touches Bennu Asteroid
description: The spacecraft attempted to suck up rocks and dirt from the asteroid, which could aid humanity’s ability to divert one that might slam into Earth.
content: [How much of Bennu did NASA’s OSIRIS-REX collect? We’re waiting to find out.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: What Pandemic? Japanese Film Draws a Record Flood of Moviegoers
description: The huge haul for “Demon Slayer” showed how audiences can quickly return in countries where they feel safe to head to theaters.
content: TOKYO — In the United States, movies are being shown to seas of empty seats, if theaters are opening at all. But in Japan, an animated film just had the biggest box office weekend in the country’s history — by far.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Our Refuge From Reality’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: My father, Seung-ho, has always had an eye for little details. About two months into sheltering-in-place, I asked him to grab me chocolate almond milk at the grocery store. When he came home with cashew milk, I started to complain that he got the wrong milk. He interrupted me, pointing to the bottom of the carton. There, in small text, it stated, “with a touch of almond.” My annoyance melted into a wide grin because I knew how hard he must have looked to find the most almond-like milk available for me. — Rachael Lee
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Is the Trump Campaign Colluding With Russia Again?
description: Giuliani’s dirty tricks are the scandal, not Hunter Biden’s hard drive.
content: The Treasury Department last month imposed sanctions on four people linked to Russia for attempting to influence the presidential election, including a Ukrainian parliamentarian named Andriy Derkach, who has worked with Donald Trump’s consigliere Rudy Giuliani to smear Joe Biden. According to the Treasury, Derkach has been “an active Russian agent for over a decade, maintaining close connections with the Russian intelligence services.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Temporarily Out of Stock
description: Jeff Chen challenges newer solvers.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Generally speaking, the assignment of a puzzle to a given day of the week determines its anticipated level of difficulty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: A Police Officer Is Killed and Another Is Wounded in Houston
description: The two officers were struck by gunfire after responding to a disturbance at an apartment complex, the police said. Chief Art Acevedo of the Houston police said a suspect was in custody.
content: A Houston police officer was killed and another officer was wounded on Tuesday morning when gunfire broke out as they were responding to a call about a domestic dispute at an apartment complex, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Tingley
title: How an Ill-Fated Fishing Voyage Helped Us Understand Covid-19
description: The threat posed by the virus makes randomized controlled trials extremely difficult. That means “real-life experiments” are especially important.
content: American Dynasty, a commercial trawler, departed Seattle one day in May to fish for hake off the Washington coast. Before leaving, its 122 crew members were screened for the coronavirus using the highly accurate polymerase chain reaction (P.C.R.) method, and all the results came back negative. But because those tests are “good but not perfect,” in the words of Jesse Bloom, a professor at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Institute in Seattle, they missed at least one case: Somehow SARS-CoV-2 found its way on board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Why the Government Is Suing Google
description: Maybe all Google needed to keep from acting like a monopoly was more effective government oversight.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Democrats Gain in Georgia Senate Races as Presidential Race Remains Tied
description: Our latest survey shows a shift toward Biden among college-educated white voters, but surprising Trump gains among nonwhite voters.
content: A shift against President Trump among white college-educated voters in Georgia has imperiled Republicans up and down the ballot, according to a New York Times/Siena College survey on Tuesday, as Republicans find themselves deadlocked or trailing in Senate races where their party was once considered the heavy favorite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Temping’ Is a Workplace Drama for One. You’re Hired.
description: An immersive work at the Wild Project asks the sole audience member to consider the value of life while role playing as an office worker involved in calculating risk of death.
content: At “temping,” a solo theater experience that begins performances at the Wild Project on Friday, there is only one seat in the house. That seat is an ergonomic office chair, facing an office cubicle. Jiggle the knob to adjust it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Kaplan, Sharon LaFraniere, Noah Weiland and Maggie Haberman
title: How the F.D.A. Stood Up to the President
description: After months of caving to pressures from the White House, Commissioner Stephen Hahn and a band of agency scientists have eked out a few victories.
content: On Sept. 23, Dr. Stephen M. Hahn left a virtual meeting of the White House’s coronavirus task force to take a call from the president’s chief of staff, Mark Meadows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Vineyard
title: Gillian Flynn Knows ‘Utopia’ Has ‘Unsettling’ Covid Parallels
description: In an interview, the author and showrunner breaks down the twists — and addresses the criticisms — of her Amazon conspiracy thriller’s first season. “I wrote it before I knew about QAnon,” she said.
content: This interview includes spoilers for the first season of “Utopia.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: When Start-Ups Go Into the Garage (or Sometimes the Living Room)
description: Labs closed in the pandemic, but innovation doesn’t stop. So while some workers have the home office, engineers have the garage.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — It is the folksiest of Silicon Valley origin stories: Tech start-up makes it big after a wide-eyed entrepreneur builds a prototype in his garage. But Colin Wessells could never have imagined that a pandemic would force him back into the garage just to keep his company going.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: A Gated Community in N.Y.C. Where Trump Flags Fly
description: Breezy Point, a private enclave in Queens, is a bastion of Trump supporters in liberal New York City.
content: Jane and Ed Deacy, who both contracted the coronavirus this summer, say their support for President Trump has only been bolstered by the way he has handled the pandemic, and even by his own battle with Covid-19. Their loyalty has also not been shaken by the president’s style in his combative debate with Joseph R. Biden Jr. or at his recent rallies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: A federal court says Tennessee can’t require first-time voters to appear in person at the polls.
description: A federal court exempted first-time voters in Tennessee from having to appear in person at the polls if they registered online or by mail.
content: A federal appeals court on Monday exempted first-time Tennessee voters from having to appear in person at the polls on Election Day if they registered online or by mail, as required by state law. Critics of the law said it would endanger residents during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang, David McCabe and Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: U.S. Accuses Google of Illegally Protecting Monopoly
description: A victory for the government could remake one of America’s most recognizable companies and the internet economy that it has helped define.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department accused Google on Tuesday of illegally protecting its monopoly over search and search advertising, the government’s most significant challenge to a tech company’s market power in a generation and one that could reshape the way consumers use the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Let’s Talk About Constipation During Pregnancy
description: Constipation is very common during and after pregnancy, but many women don’t discuss it with their doctors.
content: Constipation may be two to three times more common during and after pregnancy, Finnish researchers report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: After the Pandemic, a Revolution in Education and Work Awaits
description: Providing more Americans with portable health care, portable pensions and opportunities for lifelong learning is what politics needs to be about post-Nov. 3.
content: The good Lord works in mysterious ways. He (She?) threw a pandemic at us at the exact same time as a tectonic shift in the way we will learn, work and employ. Fasten your seatbelt. When we emerge from this corona crisis, we’re going to be greeted with one of the most profound eras of Schumpeterian creative destruction ever — which this pandemic is both accelerating and disguising.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Virus in Three Charts
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Let’s check in on the state of the coronavirus this morning, with help from three charts. Here’s the first:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Don Clark
title: Intel Casts Off More Memory Chip Business in $9 Billion Deal
description: The sale to SK Hynix of South Korea includes a major factory in China and follows the company’s decades-long shift into microprocessors.
content: Intel moved to further distance itself from its original business, reaching a deal to sell a remaining memory chip unit to SK Hynix of South Korea for $9 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Sydney Ember
title: Trump and Biden will be muted during parts of Thursday’s debate.
description: The debate commission plans to mute President Trump and Joe Biden during portions of the final debate.
content: President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. will be muted during portions of Thursday’s final presidential debate, an effort by the organizers to avoid the unruly spectacle that played out at the candidates’ first meeting in Cleveland last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Wear Your Heart on Your Feet
description: For lovers of all things sprinkles, there’s a new shoe collaboration between Vans and Flour Shop.
content: The signature of the Flour Shop bakery in SoHo — owned by Amirah Kassem and her husband, Ross Harrow — is sparkly sprinkle-strewn rainbow-striped confections, especially birthday cakes. Now Vans, a California footwear and apparel company, has taken the Flour Shop look as inspiration for its new line. Glittery footwear for all ages with rainbow decorations, T-shirts, sunglasses and backpacks hew to the theme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Researchers are planning to intentionally infect volunteers with the coronavirus.
content: Researchers in London are planning to deliberately infect people with the coronavirus in the world’s first attempt to study how vaccinated people respond to the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Sam Smith Is Finding a Place Inside Queer Spaces
description: Preparing to release their third album, “Love Goes,” the singer and songwriter talked about the films, club nights and images on their list of cultural must-haves.
content: Sam Smith needs to dance. Nearly every night during the pandemic, Smith has twirled around in the garden, blasting Robyn via headphones. The Grammy-winning singer and songwriter — who came out as nonbinary last year, and uses they/them pronouns — may be best known for slow, simmering ballads about heartbreak and despair. But their new album, “Love Goes,” due Oct. 30, delves into sleek, thoroughly danceable pop. “I just wanted to make something that felt lighter to me,” the musician said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Pivotal Senate Race in North Carolina
description: The contest in the purple state could determine which party controls the chamber. And if the stakes weren’t high enough, the battle has suddenly convulsed.
content: In the struggle to control the U.S. Senate, one race in North Carolina — where the Republican incumbent, Thom Tillis, is trying to hold off his Democratic challenger, Cal Cunningham — could be crucial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: In ‘Lobster War,’ Indigenous Canadians Face Attacks by Fishermen
description: A battle over the lucrative lobster industry in Nova Scotia has become the latest flash point in a series of abuses of Indigenous people in Canada.
content: Jason Marr, an Indigenous lobsterman in Nova Scotia, was unloading his live catch at a storage facility last week when, he said, an angry mob of 200 commercial fishermen began pounding on the door, screaming to be let in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: After Doping Scandal, Russia Hacked the Olympics, U.S. and Britain Say
description: After suffering embarrassment over its doping scheme, Russia tried cyberattacks against the 2018 Winter Olympics in South Korea and was targeting the postponed Tokyo Olympics too, American and British officials said.
content: LONDON — After the unmasking of its state-orchestrated doping program  turned it into a sporting pariah, Russia hardly quietly accepted its punishment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Fiancée Sues Saudi Crown Prince Over Khashoggi Killing
description: The fiancée of the slain Washington Post journalist sued Prince Mohammed bin Salman in an attempt to learn more about the 2018 killing.
content: WASHINGTON — The fiancée of the slain Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi accused Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia in a lawsuit on Tuesday of murder and dismemberment in an attempt to silence Mr. Khashoggi’s criticism of the kingdom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1945: Strike Paralyzes Argentina
description: A 24-hour walkout backed by the government to show support for Col. Juan D. Peron brought the country to a standstill.
content: Special to The European Edition
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jameson Fitzpatrick
title: As Far as Luc Tuymans Is Concerned, Nothing Is Original
description: In advance of a new exhibition, the acclaimed Belgian artist discusses his process and how the pandemic has shifted his perspective.
content: The celebrated Belgian painter Luc Tuymans is best known for his uncanny renderings of existing images. Often working from photographs or film, Tuymans does not paint straight reproductions, but disquieting versions of characters and scenes from cultural memory — at once familiar and made strange by his signature muted tones. His work “The Secretary of State” (2005), which is in the Museum of Modern Art’s permanent collection, is a desaturated and tightly cropped close-up of Condoleezza Rice, squinting as though she has been caught with the sun in her eyes or in a moment of deliberation. Many of Tuymans’s notable early paintings concern the Holocaust, including “Gas Chamber” (1986), which he adapted from a watercolor he painted on-site at Dachau, and “Schwarzheide” (1986), based on a background detail of pine trees from a 1945 drawing of the titular concentration camp by survivor Alfred Kantor. Alongside the horrors of war and imperialism, everyday objects and popular iconography have recurred in Tuymans’s paintings throughout his career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Frances Robles
title: Is Florida, the recount state, ready for the election?
description: More than two decades of scandals and blunders have made Florida the nation’s elections punchline, the state that kept the world at the edge of its seat while votes for president were manually recounted.
content: More than two decades of scandals and blunders have made Florida the nation’s elections punchline, the state that kept the world at the edge of its seat while votes for president were manually recounted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Marine General Removed After Subordinates Say He Used Racial Slur
description: The Marine Corps said it relieved Maj. Gen. Stephen M. Neary from his role overseeing forces in Europe and Africa “due to a loss of trust and confidence in his ability to serve in command.”
content: WASHINGTON — A two-star general recently assigned to command Marine forces in Europe and Africa has been relieved of duty amid an investigation into whether he used a racial slur during a training exercise last summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: The Big Role That Big Donors Still Play, Quietly, for Joe Biden
description: The Biden campaign has trumpeted its success with small donations, but in the last six months it has raised almost $200 million from donors who gave at least $100,000. As sums have grown, transparency has diminished.
content: One Monday evening last month, Hillary Clinton and Senator Kamala Harris, and two actors who portrayed them on “Saturday Night Live,” Amy Poehler and Maya Rudolph, gathered for a virtual fund-raiser benefiting the Biden campaign. By all accounts, the livestream was a smashing success: about 100,000 people watched and donated. The event raised $4.4 million.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Antitrust Lawsuit Against Google
description: Here’s the U.S. government’s case against Google.
content: Here’s the U.S. government’s case against Google.

author: By Nikita Stewart and Todd Heisler
title: 1.5 Million New Yorkers Can’t Afford Food. Pantries Are Their Lifeline.
description: Thousands more New Yorkers have showed up at the city’s food banks since the pandemic began. As federal and city benefits are tied up in politics, New Yorkers are left to figure out how to get by.
content: Thousands more New Yorkers have showed up at the city’s food banks since the pandemic began. As federal and city benefits are tied up in politics, New Yorkers are left to figure out how to get by.

title: A New World of Worry
description: The opioid crisis had already turned Rhea Kelsall’s life upside down. Now, amid the pandemic, she worries about her own survival.

description: For a tech investor and a radiologist who collects art, having a workable second home was even more important than finding one directly on a lake.

title: Corrections: Oct. 20, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Oct. 20, 2020.
content: An article on Monday about the two children Judge Amy Coney Barrett and her husband adopted from Haiti misstated the school that Libien Becker attends. It is Montana Technological University, not Montana Technical University.
